docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 7 APPEAL TO THE COURT OF APPEAL [ss 101–110]

heading.title: PART 7 APPEAL TO THE COURT OF APPEAL [ss 101–110]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 7 APPEAL TO THE COURT OF APPEAL [ss 101–110]

leg:heading.title: APPEAL TO THE COURT OF APPEAL [ss 101–110]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 101] s 101 Appeal in proceedings before the Court

leg:heading.title: Appeal in proceedings before the Court

p.text: Subject to this and any other Act and subject to the rules, an appeal shall lie to the Court of Appeal from:
any judgment or order of the Court in a Division; and
without limiting the generality of paragraph (a) —
any opinion, decision, direction or determination of the Court in a Division on a stated case;
any exercise of a power to which section 24 applies; and
any determination of the Court in a Division in proceedings remitted under subsection (4) of section 51.
An appeal shall not lie to the Court of Appeal, except by leave of the Court of Appeal, from:
an order in proceedings in the Court directing an amendment of a judgment or order correcting a clerical mistake in the judgment or order or an error arising from an accidental slip or omission;
[repealed]
a judgment given or order made in proceedings in the Court with the consent of the parties or as to costs only which are in the discretion of the Court;
[repealed]
an interlocutory judgment or order in proceedings in the Court;
a judgment or order in proceedings in the Court on an interpleader issue decided in a summary way pursuant to the rules;
[repealed]
an order of the Court in a Division on an appeal under Part 5 of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001,
[repealed]
[repealed]
a judgment or order of the Court in a Division on an application for summary judgment under the rules;
a judgment or order of the Court on an application under, section 74K , 74MA or 74O of the Real Property Act 1900;
a judgment or order of the Court in a Division for the winding up of a corporation;
a judgment or order of the Court in a Division restraining or refusing to restrain the presentation or advertisement of an application for the winding up of a corporation;
a judgment or order of the court on an application under section 459G of the Corporations Law or section 459G of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth;
a judgment or order in proceedings of the Court with respect to the taxation or assessment of costs, or
a final judgment or order in proceedings of the Court, other than an appeal:
that involves a matter at issue amounting to or of the value of $100,000 or more, or
that involves (directly or indirectly) any claim, demand or question to or respecting any property or civil right amounting to or of the value of $100,000 or more.

[subs (2) am Act 153 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 16 ; Act 166 of 1984 s 3 and Sch 1(1) ; Act 209 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 35 ; Act 250 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 111 of 1992 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 87 of 1993 s 4 and Sch 6 ; Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 47 of 1997 s 7 and Sch 5 ; Act 141 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 137 of 1998 s 4 and Sch 2 ; Act 34 of 2001 Sch 4 ; Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2 ; Act 80 of 2008 s 21 and Sch 2 effective 1 December 2008 ; Act 61 of 2010 Sch 2.18, effective 1 October 2010]
Subsection (2) does not apply to a judgment given or order made on an application for a writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum or to an order for the committal or arrest of any person.

Where the Court in a Division exercises any power to which section 24 applies and exercise of the power is expressed by any provision of an Act or Imperial Act in force immediately before the commencement of this Act to be final or without appeal, an appeal shall lie to the Court of Appeal notwithstanding that provision, but only by leave of the Court of Appeal.
An appeal lies to the Court of Appeal from any judgment or order of the Court in a Division in any proceedings that relate to contempt (whether civil or criminal) of the Court or of any other court.
[subs (5) insrt Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

Subsection (5) does not confer on any person a right to appeal from a judgment or order of the Court in a Division in any proceedings that relate to criminal contempt, being a judgment or order by which the person charged with contempt is found not to have committed contempt.
[subs (6) insrt Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]
[s 101 subst Act 41 of 1972 s 9 heading ; Act 47 of 1997 s 7 and Sch 5]

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.5] Rights of appeal & related provisions

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 Section 102, Sections 103, 104, Sections 105–108, s 75A.

This section provides the principal authority for appeals to the Court of Appeal, whether by right or by leave, in non-jury proceedings in the Supreme Court. Section 102 confers an equivalent right in proceedings involving a jury trial. In addition, rights of appeal from decisions of other courts or tribunals are conferred by a range of other statutory provisions. The main provisions relating to rights of appeal to the Court of Appeal (including rights contingent upon leave) are set out at [51.22.10] .

The current section should be read with other provisions of the Supreme Court Act, Rules and Practice Notes, to obtain a sound understanding of appellate practice and procedures. For example, s 75A of the Supreme Court Act deals with the powers of the Court of Appeal in non-jury proceedings. The commentary to s 75A contains important notes about the exercise of the appeal power and the remedies available on appeal. Sections 103 and 104 contain additional restrictions on rights of appeal. Sections 105–108 contain further provisions specifically relating to jury trials. All of these sections need to read in the light of the detailed rules in UCPR Pts 50 (Appeals to the court) and 51 (Court of Appeal), and SCR Pt 51B (Appeals to the court under Pt 5 of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001). Finally, Practice Note SC CA 1 (Court of Appeal — General) imposes additional requirements for the conduct of appeal proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.7] Rights of appeal — orders relating to contempt

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(1), subs (5), s 101(6), s 101A.

heading.title: Rights of appeal — orders relating to contempt

p.text: The general right of appeal in s 101(1) is “subject to this and any other Act”. The generality of that provision must be read subject to the express terms of subs (5) so that this is now the relevant source of appeal rights with respect to a finding of contempt. In proceedings relating to criminal contempt, there is no right to appeal against a finding that a person has not committed a contempt and no question of leave to appeal arises: SCA s 101(6) ; Markisic v Commonwealth [2006] NSWCA 150; BC200604474 . The exclusion in s 101(6) extends to any form of judgment by which a person is found “not to have committed contempt”, this wording not being dependent on the precise terms of the order made. There is no requirement that there be a full hearing on the merits and the exclusion is satisfied by a finding that there is “no evidence” to support the charge: Markisic v Commonwealth [2006] NSWCA 150; BC200604474 at [12] ; see also [55.13.6].

This exception to the right of appeal is consistent with the general principle of the criminal law that a person put in jeopardy once with respect to an offence, and acquitted or discharged, should not again be liable to prosecution for that offence on a further occasion. However, a question of law arising concerning criminal contempt may be referred to the Court of Appeal under s 101A of the Supreme Court Act 1970: Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 .

The distinction between “civil” and “criminal” contempt is notoriously problematic: see SCR Pt 55.0.1 . A simple basic distinction is that “civil” contempt is concerned with disobedience to court orders, and remedial applications by the person seeking the benefit of the order. On the other hand “criminal” contempt is concerned with conduct that more generally interferes with the judicial process — though it extends to deliberate disregard of orders. This simple distinction between the two concepts is difficult to maintain. Where the question of contempt arises in connection with implied obligations, rather than express orders, there is a view in favour of attempting to assess the “substance” of the proceedings and to determine whether or not they were in aid of the claim or relief sought in the principal proceedings. Applying that test an appeal lay from the dismissal of a contempt charge for breach of the implied undertaking against the use of documents for purposes extraneous to the proceedings for which they were provided: Street v Hearne (2007) 70 NSWLR 231; [2007] NSWCA 113; BC200706638 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.10] Right to appeal — judgments and orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(1)(b).

heading.title: Right to appeal — judgments and orders

p.text: The rights of appeal conferred by this section are, except for the special provisions in s 101(1)(b) , applicable only to "judgments and orders" and only to the extent that they are adverse. Difficulties may sometimes arise in characterising a particular judicial determination as a judgment or order. The term “judgment” is often used as a convenient abbreviation for “reasons for judgment”, but a “judgment or order” in the context of a fight of appeal means an operative judicial act, ie the formal judgment or order which when entered is binding on the parties and definitive of legal rights: Driclad Pty Ltd v Federal Commissioner of Taxation (1968) 121 CLR 45 at 64; 42 ALJR 355; 10 AITR 736; BC6800740 ; Moller v Roy (1975) 132 CLR 622 at 625, 632, 639; 6 ALR 321; 49 ALJR 311; BC7500039 ; Legal Practitioners Complaints Committee v A Practitioner (1987) 46 SASR 126 at 127 .
The following cases illustrate some examples and highlight the difficulties that can arise.

heading.title: Examples of judgments and orders capable of appeal

p.text: a ruling on privilege was an order (Attorney-General (NSW) v Stuart (1994) 34 NSWLR 667 at 670, 673 );
ruling on a stay application was an interlocutory judgment or order (R v King (2003) 59 NSWLR 472 at [20] );
discretionary rejection of evidence was an interlocutory order (R v Bozatsis; R v Spanakakis (1997) 97 A Crim R 296 at 302–4 ).

heading.title: Examples of rulings and decisions not capable of appeal

p.text: The following rulings and decisions have not been regarded as judgments or orders capable of appeal:

a ruling in favour of the admissibility of evidence (Ampolex Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (NSWCA, Mahoney P, 20 May 1996, unreported) (Meagher JA agreeing); Commonwealth v Mullane (1961) 106 CLR 166 at 169; [1962] ALR 67 at 68 ; R v Steffan (1993) 30 NSWLR 633 at 639 (a ruling on evidence is not an interlocutory judgment or order within the meaning of s 5F of the Criminal Appeal Act));
refusal of leave to appeal (Lane v Esdaile [1891] AC 210 (no right of appeal against); Roy Morgan Research Centre Pty Ltd v Cmr of State Revenue (2001) 181 ALR 307; 75 ALJR 1342 );
interim determination of issues — no appeal (Landsal Pty Ltd (in liq) v REI Building Society (now Co-op Building Society of South Australia) (1993) 41 FCR 421; 113 ALR 643 );
report delivered in the exercise of a statutory power of investigation and report (Ah Toy v Registrar of Companies (1985) 10 FCR 280; 61 ALR 583 ).
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCA s 17, SCA Sch 3.
(NSW) Criminal Appeal Act 1912.
(CTH) Customs Act 1901 248, ss 241, 247.

Under SCA s 17 and SCA Sch 3 , the Act and rules do not apply to various kinds of criminal proceedings: see also [SCA s 17.5] . However, some statutory provisions expressly permit criminal proceedings to be brought in the court’s civil jurisdiction. In such a case any right to appeal arises under the present section, rather than under the Criminal Appeal Act 1912 : Parker v Comptroller-General of Customs [2007] NSWCA 348; BC200710596 at [38] per Basten JA, Mason P and Tobias JA agreeing (appeal from conviction for federal offence under ss 241 , 247 and 248 of the Customs Act 1901).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.15] Right to appeal — defendants, cross-claim parties, interveners and non-parties

heading.title: Right to appeal — defendants, cross-claim parties, interveners and non-parties

p.text: A defendant may appeal where it is prejudiced by a judgment in favour of another defendant: Unsworth v Cmr for Railways (1958) 101 CLR 73 at 88, 94–5; [1958] ALR 793 at 801, 805 ; James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Seltsam (1998) 196 CLR 53 at 63; 159 ALR 268 at 273–4; [1998] HCA 78; BC9806759 ; Oceanic Crest Shipping Co v Pilbara Harbour Services Pty Ltd (1986) 160 CLR 626 at 670–2; 66 ALR 29 at 58–9 ; Insurance Exchange of Australasia Group v Dooley (2000) 50 NSWLR 222 at 228; [2000] NSWCA 159; BC200004689 . Cross-claim parties may appeal where they are affected by the determination of issues between plaintiffs and defendants: Helicopter Sales (Aust) Pty Ltd v Rotor-Work Pty Ltd (1974) 132 CLR 1; 4 ALR 77 ; Insurance Exchange of Australasia Group v Dooley , above, at 230, 233. The right of appeal extends to persons who intervene in the proceedings: Attorney-General (Cth) v R (1957) 95 CLR 529; [1957] AC 288 (Boilermakers' case); at least where the power to intervene expressly confers on the intervener the status of a party to the proceedings: Ampolex Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (1995) 37 NSWLR 405 . A person affected by the decision may seek leave to appeal even where they are not formally parties to the proceedings: Cuthbertson v Hobart Corp (1921) 30 CLR 16 at 25 ; Witness v Marsden (2000) 49 NSWLR 429; [2000] NSWCA 52; BC200001106 (witness appealing against refusal to make a pseudonym order); Commonwealth v Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union (2000) 98 FCR 31; 171 ALR 379; [2000] FCA 453; BC200001727 (subpoena recipient unsuccessfully claiming privilege); Re Markham; Markham v Markham (1880) 16 Ch D 1 (leave granted to a will beneficiary in administration proceedings); Senior v Holdsworth; Ex parte Independent Television News Ltd [1976] QB 23 at 32; [1975] 2 All ER 1009 at 1014 (leave granted to subpoena recipient). See also [33.4.5] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.20] Reasons for decision — no ″right″ of appeal

heading.title: Reasons for decision — no "right" of appeal

p.text: Published judicial reasons are not themselves judgments: R v Ireland (1970) 126 CLR 321; [1970] ALR 727 ) and no right of appeal lies against individual findings contained in them: Murphy v Abi-Saab (1995) 37 NSWLR 280; BC9505070 ; Commonwealth v Bank of New South Wales [1950] AC 235 at 294; (1949) 79 CLR 497 ; Driclad Pty Ltd v FCT (1968) 121 CLR 45 at 64 ), unless those individual findings are capable of affecting the outcome of the proceedings: Australian Telecommunications Commission v Colpitts (1986) 12 FCR 395; 67 ALR 301 ; Savage v Lunn (BC9800548, NSWCA, Sheppard AJA, Handley and Sheller JJA, No 40564/96, 9 March 1998, unreported). On the other hand, the inadequacy of the reasons given by the trial judge may itself provide grounds of appeal: see [SCR 36.2.10] as to the scope of the obligation to give reasons. But an appellate court faced with such a ground of appeal will be careful not to engage in an overcritical analysis of the reasons for judgment. Rather, the trial judge's reasons will be considered as a whole in order to assess whether the necessary factual findings have been made and the relevant legal principles properly applied: Nominal Defendant v Hekeik (1999) 30 MVR 145; [1999] NSWCA 376; BC9906877 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 51.10–51.15, r 51.14.

The requirement of leave to appeal is designed to restrict the appeal procedure to appropriate matters and thereby promote the efficiency of the court's appeal procedures: Coulter v R (1988) 164 CLR 350 at 359; 76 ALR 365 at 370; [1988] HCA 3; BC8802587 per Deane and Gaudron JJ; Carolan v AMF Bowling Pty Ltd (t/as Bennetts Green Bowl) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Sheller and Cole JJA, No 40421/92, 16 November 1995, unreported, BC9501771) (applicant for leave must demonstrate something more than that the trial judge was arguably wrong); Zelden v Sewell [2011] NSWCA 56; BC201101403 (leave to appeal refused); Jaycar Pty Ltd v Lombardo [2011] NSWCA 284; BC201107097 (leave to appeal refused on liability — no question of principle, not issue of public interest, disproportionate amount of time and cost); Be Financial Pty Ltd as Trustee for Be Financial Operations Trust v Das [2012] NSWCA 164; BC201203956 (leave to appeal refused — discussion of principles relevant to leave applications). Failure to obtain the required leave requires a purported appeal to be dismissed as incompetent: see Render v Honourable Gleeson [1999] NSWCA 154; BC9902724 and UCPR rr 51.10–51.15 . Provided there is one ground on which the court is minded to grant leave to appeal, the court may grant leave to appeal generally and not discriminate between those issues with respect to which leave is granted and other issues: Callow v Rupchev [2009] NSWCA 148; BC200905098 at [4] (leave granted leave with respect to each issue raised).

The general practice in dealing with applications for leave to appeal is to limit counsel to 20 minutes each. Desirably, the cost of a leave application should be a small proportion of the total appeal costs. Where a matter is set down for separate hearing of the leave application, it is the responsibility of counsel to ensure that the critical issues are properly raised in the summary of argument and that the relevant material is before the court: Be Financial Pty Ltd as Trustee for Be Financial Operations Trust v Das [2012] NSWCA 164; BC201203956 at [42] . The court has power to direct that an application for leave and the prospective appeal or cross-appeal be heard concurrently: see UCPR r 51.14 and notes.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.30] Criteria for leave to appeal

p.text: The High Court has expressly said it is unnecessary and unwise to lay down rigid rules of practice or exhaustive criteria governing the grant of leave to appeal: Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170 at 175; 35 ALR 625 ; Oldfields Pty Ltd v Alfar (1996) 70 ALJR 560 . No one general principle applies. The basic proposition governing the discretion is that leave should only be granted where there are substantial reasons to allow an appellate review: Johnson Tiles Pty Ltd v Esso Australia Ltd (2000) 104 FCR 564; (2001) ATPR ¶41-794 ; Australian Dairy Corp v Murray Goulburn Co-op Co Ltd [1990] VR 355 at 364 . Applying that basic proposition ultimately involves a decision that is essentially one of impression — although one that may require detailed analysis and will involve different considerations according to the nature of the judgment or order and the requirement for leave in the particular case. For example, it will generally be important to consider the extent to which the proposed appeal involves a matter of general principle or is essentially a mere matter of "practice and procedure". In either case, the amount in dispute may, having regard to the requirement for leave in small appeals, may introduce a further consideration restricting the appropriateness of granting leave.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.35] Error of principle or substantial injustice

heading.title: Error of principle or substantial injustice

p.text: It has been said that leave to appeal should not be granted unless the judgment appealed from involves both an error of principle and resulting substantial injustice: Minogue v Williams (2000) 60 ALD 366; [2000] FCA 125; BC200000306 ; BHP Petroleum Pty Ltd v Oil Basins Ltd [1985] VR 756 at 758 ; Niemann v Electronic Industries Ltd [1978] VR 431 at 441 ; Perry v Smith (1901) 27 VLR 66 ; Darrell Lea (Vic) Pty Ltd v Union Assurance Society of Australia Ltd [1969] VR 401 at 407 . But it is necessary to bear in mind the High Court's warning that it is both unnecessary and unwise to lay down rigid and exhaustive criteria: Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170 at 175; 35 ALR 625 ; Fredericks v May (1973) 47 ALJR 362 at 364 ; Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd (No 4) (1986) 6 NSWLR 674. Accordingly, the true position is that the requirements of error and injustice are neither necessarily cumulative (De Mestre v AD Hunter Pty Ltd (1952) 77 WN (NSW) 143 at 146 ) nor mutually exclusive. In some cases it may be appropriate to refuse leave where no error of principle can be shown: Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379; 104 ALR 165 (failure to comply with directions). In other cases it may be a sufficient injustice to warrant granting leave if refusal would prevent a claim or defence being dealt with on its merits. Thus, in Eltran Pty Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1991) 32 FCR 195, the Full Court of the Federal Court expressed the view that where the interlocutory order effectively determines the substantive rights between the parties, that consideration may itself be a significant factor in favour of granting leave to appeal: Ex parte Bucknell (1936) 56 CLR 221 at 226; [1937] ALR 232 ; Carr v Finance Corp of Australia Ltd (No 1) (1981) 147 CLR 246 at 248; 34 ALR 449 at 451 ; Garrard (t/as Arthur Anderson & Co) v Email Furniture Pty Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 662 at 664–5 . In such cases it may be sufficient to justify granting leave if the decision is sufficiently doubtful as to warrant reconsideration on appeal: Niemann v Electronic Industries Ltd [1978] VR 431 ; see also Decor Corp Pty Ltd v Dart Industries Inc (1991) 33 FCR 397; 104 ALR 621 ; Philip Morris (Aust) Ltd v Nixon (2000) 170 ALR 487; [2000] FCA 229; BC200000845 (leave to appeal on a pleading point in representative proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.40] Reasons for the grant or refusal of leave

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.15).

heading.title: Reasons for the grant or refusal of leave

p.text: Perhaps partly because the decision to grant or refuse leave is often largely a matter of impression, and partly because of the requirements of practical efficiency, the practice of the Court of Appeal is not to deliver reasons for decisions to grant or refuse leave to appeal — except in special cases: American Home Assurance Co v Ampol Refineries Ltd (1987) 10 NSWLR 13 at 19 ; Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (No 2) (1990) 21 NSWLR 200 at 215, 218 (short reasons given). But this practice is not inflexible. In many, if not most cases, the reasons will be apparent from the content of the written submissions and arguments and from the course of oral argument: Kiama Constructions Pty Ltd v Davey (1996) 40 NSWLR 639 per Mahoney JA. In other cases it may be appropriate for the court to provide reasons for refusing leave to appeal: Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Mahoney P, Priestley and Clarke JJA, 22 March 1996, unreported, BC9630459) (reasons given); Nine Network Australia Pty Ltd v News Ltd (NSWCA, Mahoney P, Priestley and Meagher JJA, No 40308/96, 29 November 1996, unreported, BC9605709) (reasons given): see also Decor Corp Pty Ltd v Dart Industries Inc (1991) 33 FCR 397 at 399; 104 ALR 621 at 623 . And, while accepting that it may be proper not to give reasons for refusing leave: Coulter v R (1988) 164 CLR 350 at 359–60; 76 ALR 365 at 370; the High Court has expressly encouraged courts to take the view that only in exceptional cases it is acceptable to give no reasons at all: Roy Morgan Research Centre Pty Ltd v Cmr of State Revenue (2001) 181 ALR 307; 75 ALJR 1342 at [24]–[26]. Where applications for leave to appeal are refused without proceeding to an oral hearing (see UCPR r 51.15) , the court will provide a memorandum outlining the reasons for the refusal.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.42] Is an order refusing leave to appeal interlocutory or final? Is a renewed application for leave to appeal competent?

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.42] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR Pt 36.16(4).

heading.title: Is an order refusing leave to appeal interlocutory or final? Is a renewed application for leave to appeal competent?

p.text: An order refusing leave to appeal is interlocutory, not final: Sanofi v Parke Davis Pty Ltd (No 1) (1982) 149 CLR 147 , at 152–3; 39 ALR 405; 56 ALJR 259; (1982) AIPC 90-009 ; Spencer Bower & Handley “Res Judicata” 4th ed 2009 p 86; Teoh v Hunters Hill Council (No 4) [2011] NSWCA 324; BC201108174 at [14] (application to set aside decision to dismiss renewed application for leave to appeal — application dismissed) note also Teoh v Hunters Hill Council (No 5) [2012] NSWCA 75; BC201202342 (4th application for leave to appeal against refusal to set aside perfected final order — no evidence of change in circumstances, no fresh arguments raised — application dismissed). A renewed application for leave to appeal is technically competent: Carr v Finance Corporation of Australia (No 1) (1981) 147 CLR 246, at 248; 34 ALR 449; 55 ALJR 397; BC8100070 and the court's power to reconsider its interlocutory orders is preserved by UCPR Pt 36.16(4) . But, in a practical sense, at least in the absence of any material change in circumstances, the refusal of an application for leave to appeal will typically take effect as a final decision: see Boulos v Martin (No 2) [2012] NSWCA 161; BC201204174 at [6] ff (notice of motion to review prior decision refusing leave to appeal dismissed).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.45] Monetary value thresholds — determining the matter in issue

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(2)(r).
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 ss 127, 130.
(CTH) Judiciary Act 1903 s 35, s 35(1)(a).

heading.title: Monetary value thresholds — determining the matter in issue

p.text: The value thresholds in s 101(2)(r) are derived from earlier versions of District Court Act 1973 ss 127 and 130 and Judiciary Act 1903 s 35 . They require leave to appeal unless the monetary threshold is satisfied.

An appeal which is not about money or property does not satisfy the condition in SCA s 101(2)(r) and leave to appeal is required: Clyne v NSW Bar Association (1960) 104 CLR 186 at 205; [1960] ALR 574; 34 ALJR 87; BC6000600 (barrister’s admission — right of admission — not property — leave to appeal required); Re DG and the Adoption Act 2000 (2007) 244 ALR 195; 38 Fam LR 122; [2007] NSWCA 241; BC200707968 at [17]–[21] ff (an appeal from a refusal to make an adoption order — leave to appeal required); GKD v Director General, Attorney General's Department [2012] NSWCA 219; BC201205504 at [1]–[5], [12] (adoption order — leave required); Director-General, Family and Community Services Re Felicity [2012] NSWCA 272; BC201206820 at [13]–[17] (custody order — leave required).

$100,000 matter in issue: The first limb of s 101(2)(r) applies to proceedings involving claims for a debt, damages or possession of property: Oertel v Crocker (1947) 75 CLR 261 at 265; [1947] ALR 519; BC4700440 per Latham CJ. This limb omits some significant words that appeared in the earlier provisions. In its altered form neither the amount of the judgment, nor the amount of the original claim, determines whether leave is required. The critical issue is the value of the matter at issue in the appeal: contrast Dunn v Ross Lamb Motors [1978] 1 NSWLR 26; Wilton v Commonwealth (1990) 12 MVR 243; BC9002606 ; Moller v Roy (1975) 132 CLR 622 at 625–6; 6 ALR 321; BC7500039 per Barwick CJ; McDowell v Baker (1979) 144 CLR 413; 26 ALR 277; BC7900086 .

In other words, the realistic value of the matter that is in contest in the appeal must exceed $100,000, otherwise leave to appeal is required: Gillard v Hunter Wire Products Pty Ltd (t/as Hunter Screen Products) (No 2) [2001] NSWCA 450; BC200107626 at [10]–[13] cited in Pegela Pty Ltd v Oates [2010] NSWCA 186; BC201005554 at [58]–[63] ; Jensen v Ray [2011] NSWCA 247; BC201106672 at [5]–[15] per Brereton J. The amount in issue meets the $100,000 threshold if the appellant satisfies the court a successful appeal would improve their entitlement by at least that amount: Pawlowska v Zajglic [2011] NSWCA 118; BC201103238 at [14] (small estate — family provision claim to 16% interest — no prospect of meeting threshold value). This is so irrespective of any doubts about the appellant’s practical ability to fully execute a judgment and recover the threshold value amount: Aroona Developments Pty Ltd (in liq) v Killen (2004) 50 ACSR 668; [2004] NSWCA 363; BC200406562 at [12]ff (insolvency proceedings — claim as unsecured creditor for debt due of $616,000, likely to realise less than $100,000 — “matter at issue” involves $616,000 not the ultimate value).

If the amounts in dispute involve multiple proceedings it is open to the court to make an order consolidating two actions which will bring the claim over the threshold for the purposes of an appeal: NSW Arabian Horse Association Inc v Olympic Co-ordination Authority [2005] NSWCA 210; BC200504695 at [24] (awards of damages of $70,000 and $39,500 in proceedings heard together in lower court).

$100,000 property or rights: The second limb of s 101(2)(r) mirrors the previous version of s 35(1)(a) of the Judiciary Act 1903. It applies to proceedings concerning injunctions, administration of trusts, or prerogative relief where, typically, the precise matter at issue may be small but can have a substantial effect on property whose value exceeds the statutory threshold: Oertel v Crocker, above,CLR at 265–7 per Latham CJ. And if the value of the affected property exceeds the threshold, it is not necessary for the leave applicant to show that the net result of the total application of the judgment would cause a net loss of equivalent value: Ballas v Theophilos (No 1) (1957) 97 CLR 186; [1957] ALR 713; BC5700350 . Because the effect need only be indirect, this second limb has a wide scope. But it is still a limiting provision. For example, in Oertel v Crocker, above, the proceedings related to leasehold interest and the freehold value of the property was held to be an irrelevant consideration.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.50] Determining the amount in issue — costs, interest and apportionment

heading.title: Determining the amount in issue — costs, interest and apportionment

p.text: In determining whether the judgment or order involves a question relating to property whose value exceeds the threshold:
the actual judgment amount, rather than the amount of any entitlement before the application of any apportionment legislation, must be taken into account: Dunn v Ross Lamb Motors [1978] 1 NSWLR 26

no award of costs is to be taken into account (unless the costs award is itself the subject of a specific appeal): Gurr v Robinson (NSWCA, Full Court, No 381/85, 10 February 1986, unreported, BC8601244) followed in Harbrett Pty Ltd v Butler (NSWCA, Full Court, No 269/88, 14 December 1989, unreported, BC8901320); Built Interiors Pty Ltd v Three Dinosaurs Pty Ltd [2003] NSWCA 290; BC200305943 at [35]
pre-judgment interest may be taken into account: included in determining the amount in issue: Graham v Proudfoot (1894) 11 WN (NSW) 91b ;

a plaintiff cannot abandon part of the claim or judgment so as to deprive the other party of a right of appeal by reducing the value of the amount in issue below the threshold value: North v Holroyd (1868) LR3Ex 69 .

The purpose of the value threshold is to give effect to the parliamentary policy of discouraging small appeals where the amount in issue does not justify the cost, delay and inconvenience of the appeal process: Carolan v AMF Bowling Pty Ltd (t/as Bennetts Green Bowl) [1995] NSWCA 69; BC9501771 , approved in Kassem v Colonial Mutual General Insurance Co Ltd [2001] NSWCA 38; BC200100671 at [74]–[77] . The essential question in any particular leave application is whether the statutory policy underlying the leave requirement is outweighed by the nature and significance of the error alleged in the judgment: per Kirby P in Gurr v Robinson (NSWCA, Full Court, No 381/85, 10 February 1986, unreported, BC8601244); Daily Telegraph Newspaper v McLaughlin [1904] AC 776 . The degree of error required to justify a grant of leave to appeal will depend on the nature of the case and, in particular, on the gravity of the subject matter, its public interest and the nature of any points of law involved: Johansen v City Mutual Life Assurance Society Ltd (1904) 2 CLR 186 at 188. The balance will tilt in favour of granting leave to appeal where the judgment is demonstrably wrong in principle: Wilton v Commonwealth (1990) 12 MVR 243 . Conversely, leave to appeal will be refused if the judgment raises no question of principle — even if the appeal is otherwise considered arguable: Dunn v Ross Lamb Motors [1978] 1 NSWLR 26 ; Zelden v Sewell Henamast Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 56; BC201101403 at [22] (no leave to appeal — costs likely to “swamp” the money sum involved in the dispute); Jaycar Pty Ltd v Lombardo [2011] NSWCA 284; BC201107097 at [46] (no leave granted to appeal concerning liability — no question of principle, no issue of general public importance, dispute already consumed considerable time and cost, damages significantly less than $100,000, not “reasonably clear” that the judge’s conclusion about liability was wrong).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.60] Appeals from interlocutory orders regulating practice and procedure

heading.title: Appeals from interlocutory orders regulating practice and procedure

p.text: Appellate courts are generally reluctant to grant leave to appeal where the order appealed from relates to a matter of practice and procedure, as distinct from involving the determination of substantive rights. This reluctance has been said to result from concern that "if a tight rein were not kept upon interference with orders of judges of first instance, the result would be disastrous to the proper administration of justice": In the Will of Gilbert (1946) 46 SR (NSW) 318 at 323; 63 WN (NSW) 176 ; White v Grogan [1972] 2 NSWLR 347; Morgan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 13 NSWLR 208 (appeal from a trial judge's decision discharging a jury). These general considerations have a special force in relation to applications for leave to appeal from decisions made during the course of a trial — particularly a jury trial: Nationwide News Pty Ltd v El-Azzi BC200407395 at [24]–[25] ; Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [34] . Consistent with this general approach such decisions relating to matters of practice and procedure are recognised as attracting the same general principles as those that apply to any appeal against the exercise of a judicial discretion. Ordinarily such a decision can only be overturned on appeal when it is demonstrated that the decision-maker either:
made an error of legal principle;
made a material error of fact;
took into account some irrelevant matter;
failed to take into account or gave insufficient weight to, some relevant matter; or

arrived at a result so unreasonable or unjust as to suggest that one of the foregoing categories of error had occurred, even though the error in question did not explicitly appear on the face of the reasoning.
See Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 at [45] and [SCA s 75A.35] .
Despite this ordinary position, and the justifiable reluctance to encourage appeals from procedural orders and directions, leave to appeal may be appropriate — either because of:
the exceptional circumstances of the particular case; or
the inherent ambiguity or potential arbitrariness of the distinction between “matters of practice and procedure” on the one hand and “substantive rights” on the other.

As to the first alternative, occasions may arise where the first instance procedural or evidentiary directions or orders may have substantial adverse consequences for the trial of the proceedings: Burden , above, at [34] (trial judge’s rulings appeared erroneous and indicated misunderstanding of the issues — unusual and hopefully extraordinary, circumstances — leave granted). In relation to the second alternative, the decision whether or not to grant an injunction pending the final hearing of proceedings may ordinarily be described as merely a matter of practice and procedure: Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170 at 177; 35 ALR 625 at 629 ; McHarg v Universal Stock Exchange Ltd [1895] 2 QB 81 at 82; Minister for the Army v Parbury Henty & Co Pty Ltd (1945) 70 CLR 459 at 489; [1945] ALR 309 ; White v White [1947] VLR 434 at 438 . But in some cases, the decision about an interlocutory injunction, whether it results in granting or refusing the injunction, may effectively determine the substantive rights of the parties: Eltran Pty Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1991) 32 FCR 195. The same is true of orders granting, or refusing, applications for an extension of a limitation period: Kessey v Golledge (1999) 30 MVR 95; [1999] NSWCA 424; BC9907768 ; Itek Graphix Pty Ltd v Elliott (2002) 54 NSWLR 207; [2002] NSWCA 104; BC200201727 at [154] [165] . Similarly, the appointment of a receiver may have a direct impact upon the rights of the parties: Christianos v Aloridge Pty Ltd (1995) 59 FCR 273; 131 ALR 129 . In all of these kinds of matters it will ordinarily be appropriate to grant leave, notwithstanding that the decision appealed from is properly characterised as either interlocutory or involving a matter of practice and procedure: Itek Graphix Pty Ltd v Elliott , above, at [154]–[165]; see also [SCA s 101.35] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.65] Appeal as of right — challenge to interlocutory orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR Pt 28.

heading.title: Appeal as of right — challenge to interlocutory orders

p.text: Although a direct appeal from an interlocutory judgment or order requires leave, an appellant who has a right of appeal may challenge any relevant interlocutory order leading to the judgment or order appealed from: Gerlach v Clifton Bricks Pty Ltd (2002) 209 CLR 478; 188 ALR 353; [2002] HCA 22; BC200202747 (order dispensing with jury); David Syme & Co Ltd v Lloyd [1984] 1 NSWLR 346; (1984) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-676; Beran v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 107; BC200401716 ; Crowley v Glissan (1905) 2 CLR 402; Bunning v Cross (1978) 141 CLR 54 at 82; 19 ALR 641 at 665 and see Sugden v Lord St Leonards (1876) 1 PD 154 at 208–9 ; Ramton v Cassin (1995) 38 NSWLR 88 ; Futuris Corp Ltd v Exicom Ltd (1995) 61 FCR 337; 18 ACSR 413 ; Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 543 at 549, 599; BC9605357 (no leave required to appeal against interlocutory refusal of leave to amend). This includes challenges to interlocutory judgments and orders relating to matters that have been determined separately pursuant to orders made under UCPR Pt 28 . No additional leave to appeal is required: Smith v Tabain (1987) 10 NSWLR 562 ; National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Manufacturers Mutual Insurance Ltd (1988) 17 NSWLR 223; Pioneer Industries Pty Ltd v Baker [1997] 1 Qd R 514. Accordingly, the availability of a potential right of appeal at the conclusion of the trial may provide a justification for refusing leave to appeal in appropriate case, although it would not justify the adoption of a rule of practice to refuse leave to appeal in all such cases: Oldfields Pty Ltd v Alfar (1996) 70 ALJR 560 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.70] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 ss 459P(2), 471B.

In various kinds of proceedings a plaintiff may have to establish an entitlement to bring or maintain the substantive proceedings. Examples of these kinds of proceedings include proceedings for extension of time under the Limitation Act 1969 or similar legislation, and proceedings for leave under various provisions of the Corporations Law (for example, ss 459P(2) and 471B ). The grant or refusal of applications of these kinds are interlocutory orders (see [SCA s 101.80] ) and require leave to appeal. But applications for leave to appeal from orders of these kinds, notwithstanding their interlocutory character, should generally be determined before the trial of the substantive proceedings to which they relate, because that course is necessary to give proper effect to the legislative policy which imposed the leave requirement: Kessey v Golledge (1999) 30 MVR 95; [1999] NSWCA 424; BC9907768 at [40]–[43] ; Salido v Nominal Defendant (1993) 32 NSWLR 524 ; Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; [1997] HCA 1; BC9700005 ; Itek Graphix Pty Ltd v Elliott (2002) 54 NSWLR 207; [2002] NSWCA 104; BC200201727 . However, there may be instances where the issues concerned in the application for leave are so closely related to the substantive proceedings that it is appropriate to stand over the application for leave to appeal until any appeal after trial: Oldfields Pty Ltd v Alfar (1996) 70 ALJR 560 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 101.75] Classification of orders and judgments — “final” or “interlocutory”

heading.title: Classification of orders and judgments — “final” or “interlocutory”

p.text: Although all judgments and orders are either final or interlocutory the difficulty of defining the borderline prompted Lord Denning MR to say that the question was so uncertain that the only thing for practitioners to do was to look up the practice books and see what had been decided on the point: Salter Rex & Co v Ghosh [1971] 2 QB 597 at 601; [1971] 2 All ER 865 ; see also Salaman v Warner [1891] 1 QB 734; White v Brunton [1984] QB 570 . The practice books that might usefully be looked at include Williams Civil Procedure Victoria, looseleaf, LexisNexis Butterworths, 1986 to date, at [I 64.01.415]–[I 64.01.450]; Supreme Court Practice (White Book), Sweet and Maxwell and Stevens (eds), Butterworths, (1985), paras 59/1/15–59/1/17; Australian Digest, 2nd ed, Law Book Co, Vol 1, Col 544 and Vol 14, Cols 742–52. The English Rules of Supreme Court 1965 (Rev) O 59 r 1A, made in 1988, lists specific judgments and orders that are to be treated as “final” or “interlocutory”.

In practice, two different tests have been formulated in the attempt to distinguish between orders final orders and those which are interlocutory. One test emphasises the practical consequences of the orders made rather than their actual legal character: Salaman v Warner [1891] 1 QB 734; (1891) 60 LJQB 624; 39 WR 547 ; Salter Rex & Co v Ghosh [1971] 2 QB 597; [1971] 2 All ER 865; [1971] 3 WLR 31 ; Standard Discount Co v La Grange (1877) 3 CPD 67 at 71; 47 LJQB 3; 37 LT 372; 26 WR 25 . The other test (which represents the position in New South Wales) looks at the nature of the application and its strict legal effect. Specifically, it looks at whether the order finally disposes of the rights of the parties: Sanofi v Parke Davis Pty Ltd (No 1) (1982) 149 CLR 147 at 152; 39 ALR 405 ; Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (No 2) (1990) 21 NSWLR 200 ; Bozon v Altrincham Urban District Council [1903] 1 KB 547 at 548; Licul v Corney (1976) 180 CLR 213; 8 ALR 437 ; Carr v Finance Corp of Australia Ltd (No 1) (1981) 147 CLR 246; 34 ALR 449 .

In Hall v Nominal Defendant (1966) 117 CLR 423 at 440; [1966] ALR 705; (1966) 40 ALJR 102; BC6600070 , an order refusing an extension of time to commence proceedings was held to be interlocutory. Taylor J explained that:

“An order made in the course of an action or suit which does not conclude the rights of the parties inter se, though it may, of course, conclude the fate of the particular application in which it is made, is interlocutory only. On this basis an order staying proceedings against one of several defendants on the ground that they are scandalous, vexatious and an abuse of the process of the court has been treated as interlocutory: Hind v Marquis of Hartington (1890) 6 TLR 267. The same view was taken of an order striking out a plaintiff's statement of claim on the ground that it disclosed no reasonable cause of action: Jones v Insole (1891) 64 LT 703 , and of an order dismissing an action as frivolous and vexatious in Re Page [1910] 1 Ch 489 ”.

A default judgment, even if it is liable to be set aside on any of the grounds set out in UCPR r 36.16, is nevertheless a final judgment: Linprint Pty Ltd v Hexham Textiles Pty Ltd (1991) 23 NSWLR 508 at 517–518, 526 ; Kowalczuk v Accom Finance Pty Ltd (2008) 77 NSWLR 205; 252 ALR 55; [2008] NSWCA 343; BC200810918 at [36] ; New Brunswick Railway Co v British and French Trust Corporation Ltd [1939] AC 1 at 21–22; [1938] 4 All ER 747; (1938) 160 LT 137 ; Kok Hoong v Leong Cheong Kweng Mines Ltd [1964] AC 993 at 1012; [1964] 1 All ER 300; [1964] 2 WLR 150 . On the other hand, the refusal of an application to set aside a default judgment is not a bar to the making of a fresh application and therefore is not a final order: Atwood v Chichester (1878) 3 QBD 722 ; Carr v Finance Corp of Australia Ltd (No 1), above; Malouf v Malouf (1999) 86 FCR 134 at 143; 167 ALR 383 at 391; [1999] FCA 284; BC9901180 (an order refusing preliminary discovery is interlocutory).
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.80] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459H.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(2)(p).
Examples of orders regarded as “final” include the following decisions:
the grant of a declaration: Becker v Marion City Corporation [1977] AC 271; (1976) 8 ALR 421 ;

an order refusing or setting aside the grant of a declaration — at least where the refusal is based upon substantive rather than discretionary grounds: A Hudson Pty Ltd v Legal and General Life of Australia (1985) 1 NSWLR 701; 59 ALR 505 ; SCF Finance Co Ltd v Masri (No 2) [1987] QB 1028; [1987] 1 All ER 194 ; compare Coles v Wood [1981] 1 NSWLR 723 ;

an order staying proceedings on the ground that they are an abuse of process because the point raised is res judicata: Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun Pty Ltd (No 1) (1980) 147 CLR 35; 33 ALR 248; BC8000125 ; Keramani v Westpac Banking Corporation [2012] VSCA 42; BC201201094 ; Leybourne v Habkouk [2012] NSWCA 212; BC201205497 .

an order granting a plaintiff’s application for summary judgment: King Investment Solutions Pty Ltd v Hussain [2005] NSWSC 1076; BC200509160 citing Thomson v DCT (VCA), 16 June 2000, unreported); Hunt v Knabe (No 2) (1992) 8 WAR 96 ; contra Schiffer v Pattison (2005) 143 FCR 328; 215 ALR 505; [2005] FCA 494; BC200502315 ;

an order made on an application under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) in relation to the setting aside or variation of a statutory demand: A-Pak Plastics Pty Ltd v Merhone Pty Ltd (1995) 17 ACSR 176; 120 FLR 227; BC9504730 ; Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Cranswick Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2004) 50 ACSR 544; [2004] NSWSC 877; BC200406203 (reduction of amount of statutory demand — s 459H of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)); but now requires leave under s 101(2)(p) of the Supreme Court Act.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.82] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Limitation Act 1969 s 58.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 13.4.
Examples of orders regarded as “interlocutory” include the following decisions:
orders made “until further order” are interlocutory: Rushby v Roberts [1983] 1 NSWLR 350 (custody and guardianship orders);

a judgment determining liability issues and leaving damages unresolved: Computer Edge Pty Ltd v Apple Computer Inc (1984) 54 ALR 767; BC8400467 ; Equuscorp Pty Ltd v Haxton (2012) 286 ALR 12 ; 86 ALJR 296; [2012] HCA 7; BC201201024 ; Triden Properties Ltd v Capita Financial Group Ltd (CA(NSW), Full Court, No 40539/93, 26 November 1993, unreported, BC9302262) (criticising Tag Pacific Ltd v McSweeney (1992) 34 FCR 438; 106 ALR 651 );

a judgment for damages to be assessed: Thomas v Bunn [1991] 1 AC 362 at 370; [1991] 1 All ER 193 at 195–6 . (Note however that in equity practice a judgment on liability with a reference for an inquiry is regarded as a final judgment, and the decision on the subsequent inquiry is regarded as interlocutory: Qu v Kuang [2008] NSWSC 991; BC200808344 at [7] (citing Spencer Bower, Res Judicata, 3rd Ed, Butterworths, London, 1996, [159]; cited in Brunninghausen v Glavanics (1999) 46 NSWLR 538 at 562; [1999] NSWCA 199; BC9903422 at [122] per Handley JA; Kara Kar Holdings Pty Ltd v Brookton Holdings Ltd (NSWCA, Full Court, 40571 of 1996, 27 March 1997, unreported, BC9700922); Derrawee Pastoral Co Pty Ltd v McConochie (NSWCA, Handley JA, CA 40642/94, 24 February 1995, unreported, BC9508046); Bromley v Forestry Commission of NSW [2003] NSWCA 252; BC200305683 at [13] ; Pollicino v Pollicino [2000] NSWCA 4; BC200001226 at [2], [7] ; Meeham v Glazier Holdings Pty Ltd (2002) 54 NSWLR 146; [2002] NSWCA 22; BC200200709 at [35] .));

a judgment or order made after the taking of accounts pursuant to an earlier order: Kara Kar Holdings Pty Ltd v Brookton Holdings Ltd (NSWCA, Full Court, No 40571 of 1996, 27 March 1997, unreported, BC9700922); Derrawee Pastoral Co Pty Ltd v McConochie (NSWCA, Handley JA, 24 February 1995, unreported, BC9508046);
an order granting leave to file a notice of appeal: Sanofi v Parke Davis Pty Ltd (No 1) (1982) 149 CLR 147; 39 ALR 405 ;

an order granting or refusing an application for a new trial: Isaacs & Sons v Salbstein [1916] 2 KB 139 ; Salter Rex & Co v Ghosh [1971] 2 QB 597; [1971] 2 All ER 865 ; Peek v Peek [1948] 2 All ER 297 ;

an order striking out a claim on the ground that it discloses no reasonable cause of action and staying or dismissing further proceedings: Hunt v Allied Bakeries Ltd [1956] 3 All ER 513; [1956] 1 WLR 1326 ; Tampion v Anderson (1973) 3 ALR 414; 48 ALJR 11 ; Little v Victoria [1998] 4 VR 596; BC9803047 ;
an order dismissing proceedings for want of prosecution: National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd v Grosvenor Hill (Qld) (2001) 183 ALR 700; [2001] FCA 237; BC200100855 ;
a refusal to extend the time for compliance with a self executing order: Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (No 2) (1990) 21 NSWLR 200 ;

an order striking out a defence and giving leave to enter judgment: Prelea v Westpac Banking Corp (NSWCA), Full Court, No 40202/92, 3 July 1992, unreported, BC9202970) applying Cox Bros (Aust) Ltd v Cox (1934) 50 CLR 314; 8 ALJR 107 ;
an order refusing an application for preliminary discovery: Malouf v Malouf (1999) 86 FCR 134; 167 ALR 383; [1999] FCA 284; BC9901180 ;
an order refusing to set aside a subpoena: R v Gray; Ex parte Marsh (1985) 157 CLR 351; 62 ALR 17; BC8501063 ; Brouwer v Titan Corp Ltd (1997) 73 FCR 241; 149 ALR 50; BC9705258 ;
an order for the restoration of a caveat: Caldar v Public Trustee of New South Wales [2003] NSWCA 187; BC200303653 ;

an order striking out a claim on the ground that it discloses no reasonable cause of action and staying or dismissing further proceedings: Hunt v Allied Bakeries Ltd [1956] 3 All ER 513; [1956] 1 WLR 1326 ; Tampion v Anderson (1973) 3 ALR 414; 48 ALJR 11 ; Little v Victoria [1998] 4 VR 596; BC9803047 ; Re Luck (2003) 203 ALR 1; 78 ALJR 177; [2003] HCA 70; BC200307344 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.85] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(2)(c).

Section 101(2)(c) requires leave where a proposed appeal to the Court of Appeal only concerns costs. Subject to any more specific provision of the Act and the Rules, CPA s 98 declares that the awarding of costs is a matter for the discretion of the court. Consequently, in order to succeed on a costs appeal, an appellant must show that the trial judge's discretion miscarried either by reason of some manifest error or consideration of irrelevant matter: Maiden v Maiden (1909) 7 CLR 727 at 742; 9 SR (NSW) 396; Wentworth v Rogers (No 3) (1986) 6 NSWLR 642 . The leave requirement is an additional restriction. Leave to appeal will not generally be granted where the decision simply involves the application of well settled principles applicable to the exercise of the costs discretion. Nevertheless, there are instances where the importance of the issues may justify the grant of leave to appeal: Piglowska v Piglowski [1999] 3 All ER 632; [1999] 1 WLR 1360 at 1373 per Lord Hoffmann; Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [1999] NSWCA 319; BC9906208 .

There is authority that an appeal that includes both bona fide substantive grounds, as well as grounds relating to costs, is not an appeal as to costs alone and does not require leave: Wheeler v Somerfield [1966] 2 QB 94; [1966] 2 All ER 305 . This decision has been followed in NSW, but without reference to contrary decisions in other Australian courts, including Re Golden Casket Art Union Office [1995] 2 Qd R 346 at 349; [1994] QCA 480; BC9404182 ; Road Chalets Pty Ltd v Thornton Motors Pty Ltd (1986) 47 SASR 532 Zelling ACJ; Thorne v Doug Wade Consultants Pty Ltd [1985] VR 433; (1985) 57 LGRA 90; (1984) 57 LGRA 41 . In this state of the authorities, there is scope to argue about the proper interpretation of the leave requirement: see Arena Management Pty Ltd (rec & mgr appointed) v Campbell Street Theatre Pty Ltd (2011) 281 ALR 304; (2011) 84 ACSR 33; [2011] NSWCA 128; BC201103285 at [129]; Dillon v Gosford City Council (2011) 184 LGERA 179; 284 ALR 619; [2011] NSWCA 328; BC201108747 at [53] and following (no leave required — followed existing line of authority and applied to s 57(4) of the Land and Environment Court Act despite differences in wording).
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.90] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(2)(c).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.
Consent judgment may be entered in the circumstances discussed in [36.1A.10] .

A judgment or order made with the consent of the parties may not be the subject of an appeal without leave ( s 101(2)(c) ). An order is only a consent order for the purposes of s 101(2)(c) if it is the result of a contractual bargain between the parties and not merely the acceptance by one party of a proposed order of the court: Aldham v Brown [1890] WN 116; Hadida v Fordham & Son Ltd (1893) 10 TLR 139; Lund v Walker [1939] 4 DLR 81 and Rogers v Curnow (1979) 22 SASR 204 . A mere consent to a procedure being adopted will not make the final order a consent order: Jackson v General Steam Fishing Co Ltd [1909] AC 523 . See also Chandless-Chandless v Nicholson [1942] 2 KB 321 at 324; Purcell v FC Trigell Ltd [1971] 1 QB 358; [1970] 3 All ER 671 ; Thwaite v Thwaite [1982] Fam 1 ; Siebe Gorman & Co Ltd v Pneupac Ltd [1982] 1 All ER 377; [1982] 1 WLR 185. Even where the consent order has a contractual effect the court retains power over its own procedure and may vary the order — by for example extending time for compliance: RD Werner & Co Inc v Bailey Aluminium Products Pty Ltd (1988) 18 FCR 389; 80 ALR 134 ; Morgan v 45 Flers Avenue Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 573 . In special circumstances a consent judgment may be set aside on appeal — for example where the terms of settlement which were given effect to by the judgment contained provisions which were beyond the jurisdiction of the court: Thomson Australian Holdings Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1981) 148 CLR 150; 37 ALR 66; BC8100114 ; where the court exercises its power to extend the time for compliance pursuant to its powers under r 1.12 : Paino v Hofbauer (1988) 13 NSWLR 193 , or where there has been a subsequent dramatic change in events: Barder v Caluori [1988] AC 20 (divorce proceedings, consent judgment providing maintenance to wife — wife's subsequent death). Apart from these special situations, a consent judgment may be set aside on any ground upon which a contract could be declared void or voidable: Harvey v Phillips (1956) 95 CLR 235 at 243–4; 30 ALJR 140 ; Deputy Cmr of Taxation v Chamberlain (1990) 26 FCR 221 at 230 . However, while an application to set aside might possibly be made on an appeal, the usual and preferable course, which has been described as “alone consistent with convenient practice” (Kinch v Walcott [1929] AC 482 at 494 ), is that separate proceedings be commenced to set aside the judgment: Ainsworth v Wilding [1896] 1 Ch 673; Spies v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1991) 24 NSWLR 691 . Where both parties consent and the rights of third parties are unaffected the court may set aside a final judgment: Permanent Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (Executor estate of Andrews) v Stocks & Holdings (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1976) 15 ACTR 45; 28 FLR 195 ; see also [40.9.2].
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101.95] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCA s 101(6), s 101A.

The appeal rights conferred by SCA s 101(5) and (6) reflect the conventionally recognised distinction between “criminal” and “civil contempt”: see [SCR Pt 55.0.1]. The basic distinction, though criticised as unsatisfactory (see Australasian Meat industry Employees Union v Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 98 at 107; 66 ALR 577; 60 ALJR 608; BC8601455 ) is between punitive orders (criminal contempt) and those that are essentially remedial and intended to secure compliance with the court’s orders (civil contempt): Hearne v Street (2008) 235 CLR 125; 248 ALR 609; [2008] HCA 36; BC200806976 at [22] and [133] (charge relating to the disclosure of evidence — civil contempt). In addition, a finding of criminal contempt requires satisfaction, beyond reasonable doubt, that the conduct involved deliberate “contumacious” disregard of the court’s order: Pang v Bydand Holdings Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 69; BC201101944 at [101], [173], [174].

There is no appeal, either by right or leave, from the dismissal of a charge of criminal contempt: SCA s 101(6) ; Markisic v Commonwealth [2006] NSWCA 150; BC200604474 . The s 101(6) exclusion of appeal avenues extends to any form of judgment by which a person is found “not to have committed contempt”. It includes a finding that there is “no evidence” to support the charge, and is not limited to findings made after a contested hearing: Markisic v Commonwealth, above at [12]. This absence of any rights of appeal from the dismissal of such a charge is consistent with the general policy against “double jeopardy”. However, a question of law concerning criminal contempt may be referred to the Court of Appeal under s 101A of the Supreme Court Act 1970: Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 . See [SCR Pt 55.0.1] for discussion of civil and criminal contempt.
There is a general right of appeal from any judgment or order relating to civil contempt, and from any finding that a person has committed criminal contempt.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 101A] s 101A Question of law concerning criminal contempt may be submitted to Court of Appeal

leg:heading.title: Question of law concerning criminal contempt may be submitted to Court of Appeal

p.text: At any time after the conclusion of contempt proceedings in which the alleged contemnor is found not to have committed contempt, the Attorney General may submit to the Court of Appeal any question of law arising from or in connection with the proceedings.

The Attorney General must submit with the question to be determined a statement of the circumstances out of which the question arose, and thereafter must furnish such further statement as the Court of Appeal may require.
The Court of Appeal has jurisdiction to hear and determine any question submitted to it under this section.
The determination of the Court of Appeal of the question submitted does not in any way affect or invalidate any finding or decision given in the contempt proceedings.

The alleged contemnor is entitled to be heard on the question submitted and, if it appears that the alleged contemnor does not propose to be represented, the Attorney General is to instruct an Australian legal practitioner to argue the question before the Court of Appeal on behalf of the person.
[subs (5) am Act 98 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 3.49, effective 24 November 2005]
The reasonable costs of legal representation of the alleged contemnor in proceedings under this section are to be paid by the Crown.

Unless the Court orders otherwise (whether on the application of a party to the proceedings or of its own accord), proceedings under this section are to be held in camera, except that an Australian legal practitioner may be present at the proceedings for the purpose of reporting the case for any lawful purpose of the Council of Law Reporting for New South Wales.
[subs (7) am Act 31 of 2000 Sch 13; am Act 98 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 3.49, effective 24 November 2005]
A person:
must not publish any report of any submission made under subsection (1) , and

must not publish any report of proceedings under this section so as to disclose the name or identity of the alleged contemnor unless the contemnor has, during the proceedings, consented to his or her name or identity being disclosed.
[subs (8) am Act 31 of 2000 Sch 13]
Any publication in contravention of subsection (8) is punishable as contempt of the Court.
In this section:
means the person charged with contempt in contempt proceedings.
means contempt of the Court or of any other court.
means proceedings before the Court in a Division for the punishment of contempt.
This section applies to criminal contempt only, and does not apply to civil contempt.
[s 101A insrt Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101A(7), (8)(a).

The Court of Appeal declared s 101A(7) and (8)(a) were invalid as an unreasonable restriction on the constitution freedom of communication on governmental and political matters: John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v A-G (NSW) (2000) 181 ALR 694; 158 FLR 81 . The amendment made to s 101A(7) and (8)(b) by the Courts Legislation Amendment Act 2000 may overcome the decision in Fairfax but s 101A(8)(b) remains in its original form.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 101A.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Appeal Act 1912 s 5A(2).

The section is modelled on s 5A(2) of the Criminal Appeal Act 1912; and is similar to provisions in Victoria: Attorney-General's Reference (No 1 of 1983) [1983] 2 VR 410 at 412; and England: Attorney-General's Reference (No 1 of 1974) [1974] 1 QB 744 at 748. It permits the Attorney-General to submit to the Court of Appeal questions of law of general importance in the application of the law of contempt. It is not intended to operate to permit the mere re-argument of questions of law that were determined in the course of the trial of the particular contempt proceedings in question: Mellifont v A-G (Qld) (1991) 173 CLR 289 at 305; 104 ALR 89 at 97 ; Attorney-General's Reference (No 3 of 1994) [1998] AC 245 ; R v J (1987) 9 NSWLR 615 at 6.

A mixed question of fact and law is not a question of law for the purpose of the section: Williams v R (1986) 161 CLR 278 at 287, 312 and 314; 66 ALR 385 at 391, 409 and 411 . The determination of a question that involves a balancing of considerations to form a normative judgment about whether a transaction, event or decision possesses a particular quality — such as being "in the public interest" — is not a merely discretionary judgment, but, subject to one qualification, neither does it involve a question of law: Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 . The qualification is that a question of law may arise in relation to a finding of fact if the evidence was not capable of supporting the finding that was made: Attorney-General (NSW) v X, above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 102] s 102 Appeal after jury trial

p.text: Where, in any proceedings in the Court, there is a trial of the proceedings or of any issue in the proceedings with a jury, an application for—
the setting aside of a verdict or judgment;
a new trial; or
the alteration of a verdict by increasing or reducing any amount of debt, damages or other money,
shall be by appeal to the Court of Appeal.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 102.5] Appeal after trial by jury

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 102.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101, s 102.

The present section confers a general right of appeal in relation to any issue that has been determined in proceedings with a jury. The right is general and is not subject to the leave restrictions contained in SCA s 101 : Bennette v Cohen (2005) 64 NSWLR 81; [2005] NSWCA 341; BC200507967 .

At common law applications for a new trial could be made to the court in banc and the procedure by way of writ of error was also available. However, there was no right of appeal as such until the Common Law Procedure Act of 1854 conferred a limited right of appeal to the Court of Exchequer Chamber from a rule to enter a non suit or verdict on a point reserved at the trial and from a refusal of a new trial: Victorian Stevedoring and General Contracting Co Pty Ltd v Dignan (1931) 46 CLR 73 at 108; [1932] ALR 22 . After the Judicature Act of 1873 appeals lay to the Court of Appeal from all trials conducted by a judge of a divisional court sitting alone: eg Potter v Cotton (1879) 5 Ex D 137; although applications for new trials arising out of a hearing before a jury continued, for a time, to be made to a divisional court: Yetts v Foster (1871) 3 CPD 437; Davies v Felix (1878) 4 Ex D 32. Eventually, such applications were also made to the Court of Appeal following the enactment of s 1 of the Judicature Act 1890: for example, Colonial Securities Trust Co v Massey [1896] 1 QB 38 at 39. The present s 102 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 is the equivalent provision.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 102.10] Grounds of appeal — jury trials

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 102.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 107, s 108, s 75A(10), s 75A(5).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 51.51.

Unlike an appeal from a decision by a judge sitting alone which, by virtue of s 75A(5) , is by way of a re-hearing and attracts the general remedial power conferred by s 75A(10) , the powers of the Court of Appeal in an appeal from a jury are limited. Under s 107 the court may substitute its own assessment of damages where it is “satisfied that... it is fully able” to do so, and other stated conditions have been met: see [SCA s 107.5] . Under s 108 the court can set aside unsupportable judgments and enter any judgment to which a party is entitled as a matter of law: Canada Rice Mills Ltd v Union Marine and General Insurance Co [1941] AC 55 at 65 ; Paquin Ltd v Beauclerk [1906] AC 161; Skeate v Slaters Ltd [1914] 2 KB 429: see further [SCA s 108.5] . Where neither of these sections applies, the court's powers are limited to ordering a new trial of the proceedings if it is satisfied that the trial has been affected by a substantial wrong or miscarriage: [51.53.5] , [51.53.10] , [51.53.20] . The exercise of any of these powers depends on establishing grounds of appeal involving some error in the trial proceedings. This general description includes the following illustrations of recognised grounds of appeal:

mistake of the trial judge in admission or rejection of evidence or in directing the jury where such brought about a real miscarriage of justice: Bray v Ford [1896] AC 44 ; Bugg v Day (1949) 79 CLR 442; 23 ALJR 508 ; Speirs v Caledonian Collieries Ltd (1957) SR (NSW) 483 ; Caledonian Collieries Ltd v Speirs (1957) 97 CLR 202; 31 ALJR 132 ; Jones v Dunkel (1959) 101 CLR 298; [1959] ALR 367 : see also [51.53.25] and [51.53.30]–[51.53.45] ;

where the jury have found a verdict that reasonable people, properly directed, could not have found on the evidence — either in relation to general issues of liability: Swain v Waverley Municipal Council (2005) 220 CLR 517; 213 ALR 249; 138 LGERA 50; [2005] HCA 4; BC200500186 (personal injury); Hocking v Bell (1947) 75 CLR 125; [1948] 1 ALR 85 (PC) (medical negligence — critical conflict of lay evidence and expert opinion); Cox v English, Scottish and Australian Bank Ltd [1905] AC 168 (malicious prosecution); Metropolitan Railway Co v Wright (1886) 11 App Cas 152 (train accident); Mechanical & General Inventions Co Ltd v Austin Motor Co Ltd [1935] AC 346; [1935] All ER Rep 22 (breach of contract); or, especially in relation to jury findings in defamation proceedings: John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Rivkin (2003) 201 ALR 77; [2003] HCA 50; BC200305159 (proven imputations rejected by jury as not defamatory — new trial); Harvey v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 255; BC200505684 at [51] (defamation — the standard is whether the appellant’s case impugning that verdict is “clear and beyond argument”); Beran v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 107; BC200401716 (jury trial under s 7A of the Defamation Act 1974 — rejection of defamatory meaning of imputations); Gorman v Barber (2004) 61 NSWLR 543; [2004] NSWCA 402; BC200407668 at [39], [46]–[47], [64], [68], [69] (proven imputation wrongly rejected as not defamatory — judgment substituted); Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Reading [2004] NSWCA 411; BC200407684 ; see also [51.53.11] ;

where there has been surprise, perjury or discovery of fresh evidence. As to surprise, each case depends on its own facts. As an example see Rowe v Australian United Steam Navigation Co Ltd (1909) 9 CLR 1; 15 ALR 339 and Isaacs v Hobhouse [1919] 1 KB 398. As to perjury, note Vasiljev v Public Trustee [1974] 2 NSWLR 497. As to fresh evidence see notes to UCPR r 51.51 . As to perjury see [51.53.140] .

where there has been a denial of natural justice in conduct of the trial: Stead v State Government Insurance Commission (1986) 161 CLR 141; 67 ALR 21 (adverse reliance on a witness after dispensing with contrary submissions); Jones v National Coal Board [1957] 2 QB 55 at 67; [1957] 2 All ER 155 (excessive interventions by trial judge); see also [51.53.50] (denial of natural justice), [51.53.60]–[51.53.80] (bias), [51.53.85] (refusal of amendment or adjournment).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 102.15] Appeals against jury assessment of damages

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 102.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 [51.53.100].

heading.title: Appeals against jury assessment of damages

p.text: The general principle governing damages appeals from the verdict of a jury is that the court should not interfere unless it is satisfied that the amount of the verdict is outside the range that could reasonably be regarded as appropriate to the circumstances of the case: Triggell v Pheeney (1951) 82 CLR 497 at 516; [1951] ALR 453 ; Carson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1993) 178 CLR 44; 67 ALJR 634 at 643 ; Progress and Properties Ltd v Craft (1976) 135 CLR 651; 12 ALR 59 . In particular the court should not approach the case by comparing its own instinctive view with the amount of the verdict: Coyne v Citizen Finance Ltd (1991) 172 CLR 211; 99 ALR 252 . A new trial will be granted on the question of damages in cases where s 107 does not apply where the damages awarded by the jury are so outrageously high or low as to be such that no reasonable jury could give them: Phillips v London & South Western Railway Co (1879) 5 QBD 78; Johnston v Great Western Railway [1904] 2 KB 250; Taff Vale Railway Co v Jenkins [1913] AC 1 at 7 ; Banbury v Bank of Montreal [1918] AC 626 ; Flint v Lovell [1935] 1 KB 354 at 360; Mechanical & General Inventions Co v Austin [1935] AC 346 at 377–9 ; Davies v Powell Duffryn Associated Collieries Ltd [1942] AC 601 at 617 ; Australian Iron & Steel Ltd v Greenwood (1962) 107 CLR 308; [1963] ALR 710 and see Luntz, Assessment of Damages, 2nd ed, Butterworths, Sydney, 1983, pp 524 et seq. A jury's assessment of damages will also be set aside where it has taken into account irrelevant matters: Chapman v Ellesmere [1932] 2 KB 455; or where the figure arrived at is clearly a compromise: Pateman v Higgin (1957) 97 CLR 521; [1957] ALR 996 ; Black v Morton (1957) 75 WN (NSW) 196 ; Kortekaas v Maslen (1958) 58 SR (NSW) 224; 75 WN (NSW) 200; Houston v Longworth [1964–5] NSWR 17 at 19; Doyle v Indo-China Steam Navigation Co Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 263); or plainly inadequate: Cousins v Bradford Kendall Foundries Pty Ltd (1986) 7 NSWLR 428; Moon v Lugame Pty Ltd (t/as Bullitt Transmissions, Dubbo) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Mahoney and Clarke JJ, CA 40461/90, 2 December 1992, unreported, BC9201448) (jury fixing special damages but failing to award general damages). See also [51.53.100] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 103] s 103 Appeal from separate decision

p.text: An appeal shall, by leave of the Court of Appeal, lie to the Court of Appeal from a decision in proceedings in the Court of any question or issue ordered to be decided separately from any other question or issue.
[s 103 am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 103.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 85.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 31.

Section 85 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 and Pt 31 of the Supreme Court Rules contains specific provisions for the separate determination of issues in any proceedings in the court. Annotations relating to the grant of leave to appeal, and to the possibility of an appeal as of right from any final judgment in the proceedings, are contained in [SCA s 101.25]–[SCA s 101.70] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 104] s 104 Exclusion of appeal from associate Judges and others

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of appeal from associate Judges and others

p.text: Subject to the rules, an appeal shall not lie to the Court of Appeal from any decision, judgment, order, opinion, direction or determination of the Court in a Division constituted by an associate Judge, registrar or other officer.
[s 104 am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 104.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 60 r 17.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 117A.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 49, UCPR 49.19, r 49.4, rr 49.8–49.13, UCPR 51.59.

Several provisions of the Supreme Court Rules, for example Pt 60 r 17 , provide for an appeal to the Court of Appeal from certain specified decisions of an associate Judge in a division. Although s 117A contemplates the contrary, no associate Judge has been appointed in the Court of Appeal. See UCPR Pt 49 (especially r 49.4 and rr 49.8–49.13 ) for the right of appeal to the Supreme Court from the decision of an associate judge where no appeal lies to the Court of Appeal. See also UCPR 49.19 for review (cf appeal) of a registrar’s directions, certificates, orders, decisions and other acts. UCPR 51.59 provides for review of decisions of the Registrar of the Court of Appeal.
Sections 106 and 107 apply to an appeal to the Court of Appeal where the appellant seeks a new trial or the setting aside of a verdict, finding, assessment or judgment—
after a trial with a jury in proceedings in the Court; or
after a trial—
with or without a jury in an action commenced before the commencement of section 4 of the District Court (Amendment) Act, 1975; or
with a jury in an action commenced after the commencement of that section
in the District Court.
[s 105 am Act 1 of 1975 s 4]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 105.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 s 102, ss 106, 107, s 75A, s 75A(2).
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 127, s 127A.

This section operates to apply SCA ss 106 and 107 to appeals from jury trial otherwise excluded from the operation of SCA s 75A by s 75A(2) . The right of appeal in relation to a jury trial in the Supreme Court is conferred by SCA s 102 . In relation to District Court jury trials the right of appeal is conferred by DCA s 127A , which is similarly worded. A right of appeal may also arise under DCA s 127 — if the act of the judge in recording the effect of the verdict is the legal equivalent of an order for dismissal: Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2009) 237 CLR 268; 254 ALR 637; [2009] HCA 18; BC200903186 at [29] — reversing Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2007) 70 NSWLR 395; [2007] NSWCA 375; BC200711460 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 106] s 106 New trial because of subsequent matters

leg:heading.title: New trial because of subsequent matters

p.text: Where, in an appeal to which this section applies, it appears to the Court of Appeal that, because of matters which have occurred since the trial, the amount of damages awarded at the trial is manifestly too high or too low, the Court of Appeal may set aside the verdict, finding, assessment or judgment and may order a new trial on the issue of damages.

The Court of Appeal may, if satisfied that special circumstances exist which render it desirable so to do, receive evidence as to matters which have occurred since the trial and which are relevant to the exercise by the Court of Appeal of its powers under subsection (1) and may make findings of fact as to what has occurred since the trial.

The findings of fact made under subsection (2) shall not be binding on the parties except for the purposes of orders under this section or under section 107 and for the purposes of any judgment given under section 107 .
[subs (3) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]

The powers of the Court of appeal under this section are in addition to its other powers to set aside a verdict, finding, assessment or judgment or to order a new trial on an issue of damages or otherwise.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 106.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A(7), (8), (9).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.51.
See annotations to s 75A(7) , (8) and (9) and UCPR r 51.51 .
Where, in an appeal to which this section applies—
