the Court of Appeal would, but for this section set aside the verdict, finding, assessment or judgment and order a new trial on an issue of the amount of debt or damages or of the value of goods;

ci:cite.ci:content: Act 21 of 1899 s 160A; RSC (Rev) 1965 O 59 r 11

p.text: the Court of Appeal is satisfied that—
without seeing or hearing the plaintiff or defendant or other witnesses; or
without seeing or hearing the plaintiff or defendant or other witnesses further than it has seen or heard them for the purpose of receiving evidence under section 106 ,

it is fully able to assess the amount of debt or damages or the value of the goods on perusal of the evidence contained in the documents before it and on the facts (if any) admitted and on the facts (if any) found by it under section 106 ; and
the parties consent to the exercise of the powers given by this section;
it appears to the Court of Appeal to be desirable to exercise the powers for the purpose of avoiding a multiplicity of trials; or

it appears to the Court of Appeal that, as a result of an error of law on the part of the trial judge or (where there has been a trial with a jury) a manifest error on the part of the jury, some item of debt or damages or valuation has been wrongly included in or excluded from the assessment,

the Court of Appeal may draw inferences and make findings of fact, assess the amount of debt or damages or the value of goods in such sum as in the opinion of the Court of Appeal the debt or damages or value ought to be assessed if a new trial were had forthwith and substitute that sum for the sum awarded in the Court below and give such judgment and make such order as the nature of the case requires.
[s 107 am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 107.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 105.
The section applies to appeal from jury trials in the Supreme Court and to the other proceedings referred to in SCA s 105 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 107.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 107(c)(i), (ii), (iii).

The language of the section makes plain the policy that the Court of Appeal should reassess the damages where it is satisfied that it is “fully able” to do so. The requirements of s 107(c)(i) , (ii) and (iii) are disjunctive: Radakovic v RG Cram & Sons Pty Ltd [1975] 2 NSWLR 751; and the avoidance of a second trial is the avoidance of a multiplicity of trials within the meaning of s 107(c)(ii) : Murray v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (1971) 45 ALJR 279 ; Precision Plastics Pty Ltd v Demir (1975) 132 CLR 362; 6 ALR 311 . Therefore, provided that the statutory limitations in the section are observed, it may properly be said that reassessment is the norm: Emery v Wilson (1974) 48 ALJR 131 ; Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Evans (1990) 21 NSWLR 564 . The powers conferred by the section may be exercised whether the trial below was before a judge alone or a judge and jury: Chirray v Christoforidis (1966) 83 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 375 . However, the limitation on the court's power of reassessment — its satisfaction that it is fully able to assess the appropriate amount of the damages — must be observed. The necessary degree of satisfaction may not be able to be achieved where the assessment depends upon questions of credit: Shehata v Montague L Meyer Pty Ltd (1976) 12 ALR 49; 51 ALJR 77 at 79–82 ; Agbaba v Witter (1977) 14 ALR 187; 51 ALJR 503 at 506 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 107.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Compensation to Relatives Act 1897.
The section applies to proceedings under the Compensation to Relatives Act 1897 . See Wawrzyczyk v Ziemelis [1968] 3 NSWR 585.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 108] s 108 Nonsuit or verdict after jury trial

leg:heading.title: Nonsuit or verdict after jury trial

p.text: This section applies to an appeal to the Court of Appeal in proceedings in the Court in which there has been a trial with a jury.

Where it appears to the Court of Appeal that on the evidence given at the trial a verdict for the plaintiff could not be supported and that, pursuant to any provision of the rules, an order ought to have been made for the dismissal of the proceedings either wholly or so far as concerns any cause of action in the proceedings, the Court of Appeal may make an order of dismissal accordingly.

Where it appears to the Court of Appeal that upon the evidence the plaintiff or the defendant is, as a matter of law, entitled to a verdict in the proceedings or on any cause of action, issue or claim for relief in the proceedings, the Court of Appeal may direct a verdict and give judgment accordingly.
[subs (3) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 108.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 s 102, s 105, ss 106, 107, 108, s 108(1), s 19.

This section applies only to an appeal “in proceedings in the Court in which there has been a trial with a jury”: s 108(1) . By SCA s 19 “Court” refers to the Supreme Court. The right of appeal in relation to a jury trial in proceedings in the Supreme Court is conferred by SCA s 102 . Accordingly, ss 102 and 108 operate together: Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2007) 70 NSWLR 395; [2007] NSWCA 375; BC200711460 at [72] ff ; cf ss 106 and 107 which apply to appeals from jury trials in the Supreme Court and to other proceedings referred to in SCA s 105 . See Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2009) 237 CLR 268; 254 ALR 637; [2009] HCA 18; BC200903186 at [22], [23] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 108.5] Verdict or judgment on appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 108.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 108(2), s 75A(10).

This section reflects, subject to the limitation required by the nature of jury trial, the powers conferred on the Court of Appeal by s 75A(10) in the case of non-jury trials. Because the jury function is to determine factual issues in the proceedings, the usual result of a successful appeal is an order for a new trial: Shepherd v Felt & Textiles of Australia Ltd (1931) 45 CLR 359 at 379; 37 ALR 194 ; Hocking v Bell (1945) 71 CLR 430 at 441; 46 SR (NSW) 251 . The new trial may be ordered on all issues, or on only those affected by the appealable error: Coroneo v Kurri Kurri & South Maitland Amusement Co Ltd (1934) 51 CLR 328 at 346; 34 SR (NSW) 444 ; Pateman v Higgin (1957) 97 CLR 521; [1957] ALR 996 (new trial limited to damages); Monti-Haitsma Enterprises Pty Ltd v Lord (1988) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-200; BC8801950; Radio 2UE Sydney Pty Ltd v Parker (1992) 29 NSWLR 448 at 472; (1992) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-200 at 61,850 ; Morgan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (No 2) (1991) 23 NSWLR 374 (new trial generally where error concerned related liability issues); Charlwood Industries Pty Ltd v Brent [2002] NSWCA 201; BC200203989 (new trial generally where perversity of jury's findings indicating a compromise verdict); Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Reading [2004] NSWCA 411; BC200407684 (new trial on all issues). However, the present section permits the Court of Appeal to give judgment, and avoid the inconvenience of a new trial, in appropriate cases. Consequently, the Court of Appeal may give judgment (or indeed make any appropriate order) where, as a matter of law, either party is entitled to have the proceedings finally determined in their favour: Hocking v Bell, above at 441 ; Edmund Weil Inc v Russell (1936) 56 CLR 34 . As s 108(2) perhaps implies, the most usual exercise of the power occurs where a respondent (for example, the successful plaintiff at the trial) fails to discharge its onus of proof, even on the most favourable view of the evidence. In such a situation, the jury verdict may be characterised as unsustainable as a matter of law: Sarma v Federal Capital Press of Australia Pty Ltd [2002] NSWCA 93; BC200201571 ; Waverley Municipal Council v Swain (2003) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-694; [2003] NSWCA 61; BC200301409 ; Shepherd v Felt & Textiles of Australia Ltd (1931) 45 CLR 359 at 379;; 37 ALR 194 ; or so unreasonable as to indicate the jury must have compromised its judicial function of rational and disinterested determination — for example, the verdict is "perverse": Charlwood Industries Pty Ltd v Brent, above.

It is much less common that the section will be available to justify a judgment in favour of a party who bore the onus of proof at the trial (because it is usually open to the jury simply to disbelieve that party's evidence): Hocking v Bell, above at 442 . However, there are situations where the issue does not depend on the evaluation of conflicting evidence and where a verdict against a claimant party would be perverse — such as the rejection of a claim that an allegation of dishonesty was defamatory: Charlwood Industries Pty Ltd v Brent, above at [66]–[68] (disputed imputation) and Gorman v Barber (2004) 61 NSWLR 543; [2004] NSWCA 402; BC200407668 (imputation not disputed) (explained in Harvey v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 255; BC200505684 at [72], [101] [105] ); Mularczyk v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 467; BC200107869 (perverse to hold that an accusation of dishonesty was not defamatory). There are other situations where it would be perverse for a jury to deliver a verdict against a defendant, and yet dismiss the defendant's claim against a third party: Stewart v Sydney County Council [1973] 1 NSWLR 444 (third party claim against insurer). It may also be appropriate to exercise the power conferred by the present rule in order to avoid a further re-trial of proceedings in which successive juries have reached verdicts regarded on appeal as unreasonable: Harvey v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 255; BC200505684 at [112] [117] (jury verdict for defendant — upheld); Hocking v Bell, above at 442 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 109] s 109 Effect of minor variations to judgments, orders or injunctions appealed against

leg:heading.title: Effect of minor variations to judgments, orders or injunctions appealed against

p.text: If:
a Judge of Appeal or the Court of Appeal dismisses an appeal against a judgment, order or injunction; and
at that time, the Judge or Court makes a judgment or order that involves the variation of the judgment, order or injunction the subject of the appeal; and
the Judge or Court declares the variation to be a minor variation,

the varied judgment, order or injunction is, for all purposes, taken to be a judgment, order or injunction of the court, tribunal or Division that made the original judgment, order or injunction the subject of the appeal.
[s 109 insrt Act 31 of 2000 Sch 13]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 110] s 110 Disqualification of Judge of Appeal

p.text: A Judge of Appeal, or a Judge appointed or nominated under section 36 to act as an additional Judge of Appeal, shall not sit on the hearing of an appeal from a judgment given or an order made by himself or herself.
[subs (1) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
Subsection (1) does not apply to a judgment given or order made pro forma by consent of the parties.
This section only applies to judges sitting in the Court of Appeal. An application to a judge to vary his or her own order is not caught by the section: Adams v Thies (1914) 31 WN (NSW) 181 .
The Court of Appeal may not consult the trial judge as to how he or she approached the matter or at all: Patterson v Barnes (1965) 39 ALJR 507 .
